description: In this series, Daniel and Mike discuss, explain, and demonstrate some of the common tools and techniques used by Penetrations Testers during a security audit. Watch as they explore topics like hacking platforms and test environments, creating BIND/REVERSE shells, discovering and exploiting Buffer Overflows, Cross Site Scripting attacks, Local and Remote File Inclusion attacks, SQL-Injection, Password attacks, Privilege Escalation, and Port Redirection.

subtitle: Tools and techniques for verifying security integrity

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike demonstrate creating remote shells. They compare and contrast BIND and reverse shells. They show how to use netcat and the NMAP's ncat.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike go over different scanning and enumeration techniques. They demonstrate host discovery, email address enumeration, service enumeration, as well as vulnerability scanning.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike begin their look into buffer overflow attacks. They explain what a buffer overflow is and what causes them. They also set up a debugger to create a buffer overflow attack.
episodes.title: Buffer Overflows

00:18:04.884 --> 00:18:07.090
But we're also doing the banner-grabbing.

381
00:18:07.090 --> 00:18:09.726
I need to know what version
of Apache they're running,

382
00:18:09.726 --> 00:18:12.370
what version of Perl they're
implementing with that.

383
00:18:12.370 --> 00:18:16.012
Because I need to set up a duplicate
environment down to the version and

384
00:18:16.012 --> 00:18:16.764
patch level.

385
00:18:16.764 --> 00:18:19.620
So that I can verify that
what I'm doing is gonna work.

386
00:18:19.620 --> 00:18:23.660
>> That's exactly right, and Mike is
nailing right on the head, yet again,

387
00:18:23.660 --> 00:18:27.469
cuz he's a fan, he knows this stuff
>> He's not just a pretty face standing

388
00:18:27.469 --> 00:18:29.832
next to me,
he's a smart man he knows his security.

389
00:18:29.832 --> 00:18:32.741
You need down to that version and
patch number,

390
00:18:32.741 --> 00:18:36.170
because those are different
programs from each other.

391
00:18:36.170 --> 00:18:38.910
Even though it's the same program per se,
if the patch number is

392
00:18:38.910 --> 00:18:42.333
different you're going to get different
results, it may work it may not work.

393
00:18:42.333 --> 00:18:45.865
So you have to be consistent
in that test environment.

394
00:18:45.865 --> 00:18:49.794
If you have a client who say we'd
like you to pen test our systems,

395
00:18:49.794 --> 00:18:52.869
Well you need pass numbers,
version numbers, and

396
00:18:52.869 --> 00:18:56.580
make a model of everything
that they want you to test.

397
00:18:56.580 --> 00:18:57.920
Build your sandboxes.

398
00:18:57.920 --> 00:19:00.940
Keep them off the internet,
cuz obviously they might be vulnerable.

399
00:19:00.940 --> 00:19:02.470
You've got to find that out.

400
00:19:02.470 --> 00:19:03.421
So just keep that in mind.

401
00:19:03.421 --> 00:19:06.133
So build that test and like I said,
we'll sit here and wait for

402
00:19:06.133 --> 00:19:07.870
you until you're done.

403
00:19:07.870 --> 00:19:10.108
Now that's done we will move on.

404
00:19:10.108 --> 00:19:11.354
What else do we need to know.

405
00:19:11.354 --> 00:19:12.670
You need a debugger.

406
00:19:12.670 --> 00:19:16.140
It's kind of this is a important
piece of this puzzle and

407
00:19:16.140 --> 00:19:17.870
something that you will need to learn.

408
00:19:17.870 --> 00:19:21.161
And the learning curve
[NOISE] is a little steep,

409
00:19:21.161 --> 00:19:24.670
just throwing it out there,
being honest with my viewers.

410
00:19:24.670 --> 00:19:29.281
I don't want them to think, man I'm just
gonna grab this debugger an go to town.

411
00:19:29.281 --> 00:19:34.091
Man I've been frustrated learning the
debugger, so get your documentation ready,

412
00:19:34.091 --> 00:19:35.911
you're gonna have questions.

413
00:19:35.911 --> 00:19:37.330
You need to learn your debugger.

I recommend Immunity because I like it,
because I've used it,

415

There are other really
good debuggers out there.

I've actually used that before

419
00:19:50.314 --> 00:19:52.885
I'll say, to do security stuff.

00:19:52.885 --> 00:19:56.999
But when I found Immunity,
I liked Immunity better for my purposes.

421
00:19:56.999 --> 00:20:00.710
So if you like OllyDbg,
great, great program.

And there's their website, looks,

00:20:22.263 --> 00:20:23.896
These people are really

00:20:23.896 --> 00:20:27.042
They help pen testers a lot,

00:20:27.042 --> 00:20:31.440
This is no exception, and there it is

00:20:31.440 --> 00:20:35.660
If you didn't land on this page,

00:20:35.660 --> 00:20:38.320
if I can that, there it is.

00:20:38.320 --> 00:20:40.988
I'm in the debugger that

And when you do,

You'll have to fill out some information,

See who's interested in their product so

00:20:53.190 --> 00:20:55.502

It installs like any other

00:20:58.035 --> 00:21:00.659
You guys know how to do that if

00:21:00.659 --> 00:21:01.988
Like I said, assume knowledge.

00:21:01.988 --> 00:21:03.833
>> [LAUGH]
>> That you know how to install

a program in Windows.

00:21:04.642 --> 00:21:07.389

>> Now once that's done obviously,

00:21:07.389 --> 00:21:10.480
you get to your package,

00:21:10.480 --> 00:21:15.548
Go over to my Windows, let me close

00:21:15.548 --> 00:21:19.443
There is my Immunity Debugger right there.

447
00:21:19.443 --> 00:21:23.380
So, to get this to work to

00:21:23.380 --> 00:21:28.314
move it the way we need it to go

Our episodes,
actually I am going to start vulnserver.

00:21:32.860 --> 00:21:34.530
I'm gonna run it as administrators.

00:21:34.530 --> 00:21:39.332
Cuz I like to keep it nice and give me,

And maybe I'm just a bad admin,

>> [LAUGH]

That's what we're hoping for, absolutely.

00:21:44.582 --> 00:21:48.560
I'm gonna run Immunity as an administrator

Remember we are going down to

00:21:51.769 --> 00:21:53.837
I typically run as administrator here.

00:21:53.837 --> 00:21:55.958
And there is our interface.

Got a lot buttons at the top,

We've got this 4 squares

You'll notice that

00:22:07.410 --> 00:22:09.390
This is something this

today with using Immunity

There's an x here and this does this.

What's going on here?

467

I don't need this screen for

I hit that x all the time,

469
00:22:22.683 --> 00:22:25.232
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which when I want to close Immunity,

which I'll do a lot of.

We're doing a lot of repetitive steps.

I tend to hit that.

To get that screen back,

You run over here to-

00:22:52.557 --> 00:22:54.012

So if accidentally hit that x as I

483
00:23:02.284 --> 00:23:06.173
But to attach a program to it,

00:23:06.173 --> 00:23:11.880
All I have to do is go over to File,

485
00:23:11.880 --> 00:23:17.856
Click attach, and then you have a list of
programs that are running on the machine.

486
00:23:17.856 --> 00:23:22.410
I like to sort it by name cuz I know v is

487
00:23:22.410 --> 00:23:25.577
And there it is vulnserver,

488
00:23:25.577 --> 00:23:29.723
I can't really actually click on it,

489
00:23:29.723 --> 00:23:33.539
Now the program is loaded

490
00:23:33.539 --> 00:23:35.742
We are seeing a lot of
activity at this point.

491
00:23:35.742 --> 00:23:41.394
You'll notice over here,
all these things like NOP or where are we,

492
00:23:41.394 --> 00:23:48.540
RETN, push, move, or, JE, these are all
assembly language instructions.

493
00:23:48.540 --> 00:23:53.326
So the lowest language before you get
into binary, there's assembly, and

494
00:23:53.326 --> 00:23:56.707
this is what it's showing you,
there's assembly.

495
00:23:56.707 --> 00:24:00.522
It's basically taking the C Code
that the program is created from and

496
00:24:00.522 --> 00:24:03.700
breaking it down into assembly so
that you can see those.

497
00:24:03.700 --> 00:24:06.030
Because that's what we want to work with.

498
00:24:06.030 --> 00:24:07.840
And over here we see
a couple other things.

499
00:24:07.840 --> 00:24:10.860
The register's a very important

500
00:24:10.860 --> 00:24:12.724
We're gonna deal a lot over here,

501
00:24:12.724 --> 00:24:15.433
we're also gonna deal a lot

502
00:24:15.433 --> 00:24:19.736
So if we wanna see what's in a register,
we send it to the dump.

503
00:24:19.736 --> 00:24:24.586
We can see what's going on there

504
00:24:24.586 --> 00:24:28.900
So, you'll also notice something

505
00:24:28.900 --> 00:24:30.891
Once you attach, yeah,
thank you very much.

506
00:24:30.891 --> 00:24:32.719
Right there,
down at the bottom right-hand corner.

507
00:24:32.719 --> 00:24:34.990
This is a paused system.

508
00:24:34.990 --> 00:24:37.538
So what it does is when you
load a program into Immunity,

509
00:24:37.538 --> 00:24:41.024
the first thing it's gonna do is load
it up and it's gonna pause the system.

510
00:24:41.024 --> 00:24:44.520
It's gonna say here it is,
does everything look good to you?

511
00:24:44.520 --> 00:24:45.233
Do you want to do anything?

512
00:24:45.233 --> 00:24:49.800
And if you're good, if you're good to go,
you come over to here.

513
00:24:49.800 --> 00:24:50.750
You got a nice little play button.

514
00:24:50.750 --> 00:24:51.680
And it should play.

515
00:24:51.680 --> 00:24:55.220
And now if you look back at the bottom
right-hand corner it says running.

516
00:24:55.220 --> 00:24:59.062
So now our our actual vulnserver
is now running again.

517
00:24:59.062 --> 00:25:03.388
It just paused for a moment cuz
immunity kind of took control of it so

518
00:25:03.388 --> 00:25:04.790
that it could see it.

519
00:25:04.790 --> 00:25:06.110
It could do stuff with it.

520
00:25:06.110 --> 00:25:08.550
And now that you say that yes,
that is happening.

521
00:25:08.550 --> 00:25:10.830
You've given it the green light,
you can hit play.

522
00:25:10.830 --> 00:25:13.453
Once it plays, you're, it just runs,

523
00:25:13.453 --> 00:25:17.861
and now vulnserver is running normally for
anybody on the outside.

524
00:25:17.861 --> 00:25:19.769
>> All right, fantastic Daniel.

525
00:25:19.769 --> 00:25:21.667
I know we've got a lot more to go, but

526
00:25:21.667 --> 00:25:25.670
I think we might be at a good breaking
point here for this particular episode.

527
00:25:25.670 --> 00:25:27.054
So we've got our environment set up.

528
00:25:27.054 --> 00:25:28.276
You know, he showed us,

529
00:25:28.276 --> 00:25:31.670
Daniel took time to show us what
a buffer overflow would end up doing.

530
00:25:31.670 --> 00:25:34.989
What our end goal was,
The Tarantino move there, start to get.

531
00:25:34.989 --> 00:25:36.835
>> [LAUGHS]
>> Come back to the beginning,

532
00:25:36.835 --> 00:25:39.900
we've defined what a buffer overflow is.

533
00:25:39.900 --> 00:25:43.923
And now we've set up our environment to
where we can start taking an application,

534
00:25:43.923 --> 00:25:46.735
looking to see if it's
vulnerable to a buffer overflow.

535
00:25:46.735 --> 00:25:49.883
I know there's a couple more things
we're going to do in the setup as well.

536
00:25:49.883 --> 00:25:53.722
But, like I said, we're out of time for
this one, so that means we're gonna

537
00:25:53.722 --> 00:25:57.700
leave you hanging on the edge of your
seat, dying to know what Daniel does next.

538
00:25:57.700 --> 00:26:01.141
Which means you're gonna come back and
watch the next part, right?

539
00:26:01.141 --> 00:26:02.386
Hopefully.

540
00:26:02.386 --> 00:26:03.302
>> That's the plan.

541
00:26:03.302 --> 00:26:04.291
>> All right.

542
00:26:04.291 --> 00:26:05.984
Well ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this one.

543
00:26:05.984 --> 00:26:09.401
We hope you enjoyed watching, signing
off for ITProTV, I've been your host,

544
00:26:09.401 --> 00:26:10.150
Mike Rodrick.

545
00:26:10.150 --> 00:26:11.887

>> And we'll see you next time.

546

[MUSIC]

547
00:26:19.002 --> 00:26:21.652
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike continue to look at buffer overflow attacks. They demonstrate using a debugger to fuzz a program and to determine if a buffer overflow attack is possible.
episodes.title: Buffer Overflows Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.092 --> 00:00:01.052
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.052 --> 00:00:01.963
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.963 --> 00:00:09.140
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:14.750
>> Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode here

5
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:15.299
at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.299 --> 00:00:19.660
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
today we're doing penetration testing.

7
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:20.530
And in this episode,

8
00:00:20.530 --> 00:00:25.110
we're going to be continuing our thought
process working with buffer overflows.

9
00:00:25.110 --> 00:00:29.430
In the previous episode, we learned
about what a buffer overflow is and

10
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:32.466
we saw the end result of
a buffer overflow attack.

11
00:00:32.466 --> 00:00:36.060
And now we're getting into
how to accomplish that.

12
00:00:36.060 --> 00:00:39.650
Again, at the very end of that last
episode, we got our environment set up, so

13
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:41.470
we would have an area to work with.

14
00:00:41.470 --> 00:00:46.210
And try to create our own buffer overflow
and so that's what we're gonna pick us up.

15
00:00:46.210 --> 00:00:48.620
So if you miss that last one,
make sure you go back and watch that one.

16
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:50.790
It will give you some good set up for
this episode.

17
00:00:50.790 --> 00:00:51.910
And enough for me talking.

18
00:00:51.910 --> 00:00:56.135
Let's dive back into it and I'll pass
the mic over to the Security guru, Mr.

19
00:00:56.135 --> 00:00:57.047
Daniel Lowrie.

20
00:00:57.047 --> 00:00:58.310
How are you doing, Daniel?

21
00:00:58.310 --> 00:01:00.010
>> Michael, thank you for having me back.

22
00:01:00.010 --> 00:01:02.820
Obviously we left you guys with
a cliffhanger a little bit.

23
00:01:02.820 --> 00:01:05.440
Well, we're probably going to leave
you with another cliffhanger, so

24
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:06.150
just be prepared.

25
00:01:06.150 --> 00:01:10.580
This is a lot of information and like Mike
said, if you didn't watch that previous

26
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:14.400
episode, it's kind of necessary because
we're building that foundation, right?

27
00:01:14.400 --> 00:01:16.650
You've got to be with us where we're at or

28
00:01:16.650 --> 00:01:20.180
at least know how to get where we're
at before we can move forward.

29
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:23.020
So that being said, we are moving
back into buffer overflows, remember,

30
00:01:23.020 --> 00:01:27.160
we talked about what they were,
how they work and why they occur and

31
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:28.730
now we're trying to make them happen.

32
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:31.130
Now we've set up our test environment,

33
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:35.770
we've loaded our vulnerable server
service into our debugging machine.

34
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:42.250
So that we can see certain pieces
of instruction that's happening

35
00:01:42.250 --> 00:01:47.530
inside of that and now we're moving on to
the next phase which is called fuzzing.

36
00:01:47.530 --> 00:01:50.660
[LAUGH] I actually love
the term like fuzzing.

37
00:01:50.660 --> 00:01:51.530
>> I like saying it.

38
00:01:51.530 --> 00:01:53.338
Say it with us everybody out there.

39
00:01:53.338 --> 00:01:54.393
>> Yeah.
>> Fuzzing.

40
00:01:54.393 --> 00:01:55.240
>> Fuzzing, right?

41
00:01:55.240 --> 00:01:55.910
Lot of fun, right?

42
00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:57.070
Say fuzzing.

43
00:01:57.070 --> 00:01:57.980
What is fuzzing?

44
00:01:57.980 --> 00:02:04.120
Fuzzing is basically trying to
figure out where the problem lies.

45
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:07.120
I guess that's a good way to say it.

46
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:10.390
So you got a service,
it takes input from you.

47
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:11.560
I wanna see whether or

48
00:02:11.560 --> 00:02:16.770
not that service is vulnerable to
a buffer overflow and implement fuzzing.

49
00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:17.970
How's that work?

50
00:02:17.970 --> 00:02:23.200
I'm going to send a data until what I'm
looking for is the program to crash.

51
00:02:23.200 --> 00:02:26.632
I want the program to crash,
because if the program crashes,

52
00:02:26.632 --> 00:02:30.602
then at least I'm on the right track
toward a buffer overflow, right.

53
00:02:30.602 --> 00:02:37.770
Cuz that means that service had no idea
what to do with the data I sent it.

54
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:41.210
Now that could be a lot of data,
to be honest with you.

55
00:02:41.210 --> 00:02:45.100
And fuzzing is a technique that helps
us figure out how much data that is.

56
00:02:45.100 --> 00:02:48.800
So we have to, because if we
don't know how much data that is,

57
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:49.880
we won't cause the crash.

58
00:02:51.520 --> 00:02:55.900

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike look at remote file inclusion. They demonstrate how to determine if a site is vulnerable to RFI. Then they use RFI to obtain a reverse shell on a target machine.
episodes.title: Web Apps Remote File Inclusion (RFI)

And that's known as RFI,

It's one of my favorites because this is

17

39

So that being said, I'll go ahead and take

40
00:02:00.570 --> 00:02:01.949

41
00:02:01.949 --> 00:02:06.370
What the heck are we talking about when
we say RFI or remote file inclusion?

42
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:12.835
So what we mean is, we are going
to include a file that is remote.

43
00:02:12.835 --> 00:02:16.196
[LAUGH] Yeah, you're like,
okay, smarty, I get it.

44
00:02:16.196 --> 00:02:20.001
>> [LAUGH]
>> What we mean is that I'm gonna have

45
00:02:20.001 --> 00:02:24.432
a file on my system, or
a remote system to the target,

46
00:02:24.432 --> 00:02:30.360
that I want to include as part of the URL,
basically, or the web app.

47
00:02:30.360 --> 00:02:33.468
So, when I run something on a target,

48
00:02:33.468 --> 00:02:37.851
a web app,
it's gonna include a file from my system.

49
00:02:37.851 --> 00:02:40.089
That's the basic gist of it.

50
00:02:40.089 --> 00:02:41.870
And what do you mean?

51
00:02:41.870 --> 00:02:43.821
How do you conclude?

52
00:02:43.821 --> 00:02:46.851
Well, sometimes when people
create websites, they say, man,

53
00:02:46.851 --> 00:02:50.140
I don't wanna download all
these files from Getty Images.

54
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:53.330
I want to just go to Getty Images and
get them.

55
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:56.805
So I'll include that,
I'll turn on some flags in my PHP code, so

56
00:02:56.805 --> 00:02:59.791
that I can include those files
from the remote servers.

57
00:02:59.791 --> 00:03:04.120
Seems like it's a very important or
a good thing to do, right?

58
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:04.711
>> Absolutely.

59
00:03:04.711 --> 00:03:07.658
>> So you're not storing all the images
that you need, Getty Images is doing it,

60
00:03:07.658 --> 00:03:09.861
or wherever that you're getting
them from is doing that.

61
00:03:09.861 --> 00:03:12.532
So this is one of the reasons
that you might wanna do this,

62
00:03:12.532 --> 00:03:13.932
you might wanna turn this on.

63
00:03:13.932 --> 00:03:20.558
Unfortunately, it opens you up, if you are
not doing proper sanitization of URLs and

64
00:03:20.558 --> 00:03:24.974
things of that nature,
then the problem lies in, well,

65
00:03:24.974 --> 00:03:29.590
I can just take that Getty Images URL
out and add my URL to it.

66
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:30.959
And now it'll look to me,

67
00:03:30.959 --> 00:03:35.960
because it's looking for a URL that's
remote to itself, and to include a file.

68
00:03:35.960 --> 00:03:39.740
This is the danger of working
with remote file inclusions.

69
00:03:39.740 --> 00:03:44.240
So, if you turn these things on, that will
be in your phpinfo file, in the setup,

70
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:45.692
in the .conf, all that.

71
00:03:45.692 --> 00:03:48.127
There will be a couple of flags,

72
00:03:48.127 --> 00:03:52.932
I wrote them down because I wanted
to make sure I got them right.

73
00:03:52.932 --> 00:03:57.279
Allow_url_fopen = on.

74
00:03:57.279 --> 00:03:59.076
And let me go to my computer real quick,
I'll type it out so

75
00:03:59.076 --> 00:04:00.890
you can kinda get a visual of it.

76
00:04:00.890 --> 00:04:03.133
Let me do this,
make these a little bigger here.

77
00:04:03.133 --> 00:04:08.925
So it'll look like this, allow urI,

78
00:04:08.925 --> 00:04:13.820
I think it's _url, _url_.

79
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:16.688
I'm sorry, allow_url [LAUGH].

80
00:04:16.688 --> 00:04:19.135
I am the world's worst typist,
as you can tell.

81
00:04:19.135 --> 00:04:20.583
Ronnie taught me well, man.

82
00:04:20.583 --> 00:04:21.824
>> You still haven't got it, sorry.

83
00:04:21.824 --> 00:04:23.022
>> You be quiet over there!

84
00:04:23.022 --> 00:04:23.768
>> It says usl.

85
00:04:23.768 --> 00:04:24.805
>> [LAUGH] Does it really?

86
00:04:24.805 --> 00:04:25.885
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

87
00:04:25.885 --> 00:04:28.627
>> Jeez, url, there we go.

88
00:04:28.627 --> 00:04:31.220
That's what it should look like.

89
00:04:31.220 --> 00:04:31.990
You've got this one, so

90
00:04:31.990 --> 00:04:37.490
if you see if that in your php.conf and it
equals on, you might wanna make that off.

91
00:04:37.490 --> 00:04:43.390
Also, as well, it'll look like this,
allow_url_include = on.

92
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:45.700
So you're allowing includes.

93
00:04:45.700 --> 00:04:48.340
So if you've played around
with any HTML and PHP,

94
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:51.490
you have these lovely
things called includes.

95
00:04:51.490 --> 00:04:54.170
We're including files from other places,
and

96
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:57.340
you're giving it information
from using that include.

97
00:04:57.340 --> 00:05:00.311
This is where the danger can lie,
and this also can also lead to us

98
00:05:00.311 --> 00:05:04.350
having problems with local file inclusion

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike look at local file inclusion. They demonstrate how to determine if a site is vulnerable to LFI.  Then they use LFI to obtain a reverse shell on a target machine.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike demonstrate how to transfer files to a compromised machine. They discuss several tools that can be used in Linux and Windows. They demonstrate transferring files using both FTP and TFTP.
episodes.title: File Transfer Fun

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike demonstrate how to escalate privileges on a Windows system using two different methods. They first use an existing vulnerability to escalate privileges. Then they use a misconfigured task to accomplish privilege escalation.
episodes.title: Windows Privilege Escalation

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike demonstrate how to escalate privileges in a Linux environment. They discuss different methods that might be used for privilege escalation. Then they demonstrate performing a lateral escalation, followed by an escalation to root.
episodes.title: Linux Privilege Escalation

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike begin their look at SQL injection. They discuss what SQL injection is and where the vulnerability occurs. They demonstrate performing a SQL injection through a form on a web page as well as by injecting a command in a URL.

533
00:28:08.120 --> 00:28:08.909
And man, did they get me.

534
00:28:08.909 --> 00:28:09.467
>> Yeah.

>> There's another one called dev

accounts up here some ways.

So those exist, so

Username, and
then I'm gonna take 3 out and

00:28:53.083 --> 00:29:00.236
call it password cuz those were
good columns and good tables.

549
00:29:00.236 --> 00:29:04.491
And I will say from the table

00:29:04.491 --> 00:29:09.118
dev_accounts, like that.

00:29:09.118 --> 00:29:12.815
And then once I did that,
we now see I've got a username,

552
00:29:12.815 --> 00:29:17.330
I've got an encrypted password,
that's a hashed password.

553
00:29:17.330 --> 00:29:20.880
But there's two usernames and
passwords that came out in those fields.

554
00:29:20.880 --> 00:29:25.048
I can now copy and paste those, which is
exactly what I did, if I come here and

555
00:29:25.048 --> 00:29:25.578
do an ls.

556
00:29:25.578 --> 00:29:30.165
I got this creds.txt cat creds and
I just copied them and

I shoved them through my password

558
00:29:36.350 --> 00:29:39.800
There's online md5 decreptors and

559
00:29:40.900 --> 00:29:42.170
And I got those passwords.

560
00:29:42.170 --> 00:29:48.432
From there, if I do a little endmap,

00:29:48.432 --> 00:29:53.079
map of kioptrics3.com,

we will use that because it uses

569

>> You don't use your right hand at all.

570
00:30:23.040 --> 00:30:23.930
And I'm logged in.

571
00:30:23.930 --> 00:30:30.100
And now I'm set up for a springboard into,

Not a root user.

I didn't try to pseudo anything,

00:30:37.920 --> 00:30:41.810
To continue on to root,

579

580
00:30:51.410 --> 00:30:54.004
And we appreciate those
great demonstrations,

581

really shows you that with a little bit of

582

as a pentester, you can take advantage of

583
00:31:02.863 --> 00:31:04.213
validating that input.

584

Allowing those commands to be processed

585
00:31:08.190 --> 00:31:12.893
And that's never gonna be a good thing
when you can let random public people fire

586
00:31:12.893 --> 00:31:16.020
SQL [LAUGH] commands
against your SQL server.

587
00:31:16.020 --> 00:31:19.214
When I say SQL, understand I'm not saying

588
00:31:19.214 --> 00:31:23.402
We're talking about Transact-SQL

589
00:31:23.402 --> 00:31:25.750
Structure Query Language.

590
00:31:25.750 --> 00:31:30.011
And just SQL database engines,
of which Microsoft SQL is one, but

591
00:31:30.011 --> 00:31:34.653
there's also MySQL, and there's
several other free and open source,

592
00:31:34.653 --> 00:31:39.319
that all use that same common language,
that Transact-SQL or T-SQL.

593
00:31:39.319 --> 00:31:44.008
So learning that is a big part of being a
good pentester, especially if you're gonna

594
00:31:44.008 --> 00:31:47.520

command injection or SQL injection.

595
00:31:47.520 --> 00:31:51.010
So, Daniel, I know we got some

So we're gonna have to call it there.

00:31:55.730 --> 00:31:59.910
We're gonna leave you hanging and

599
00:31:59.910 --> 00:32:03.450
we'll finish up or at least

600

So thank you for that, Daniel.

601
00:32:04.320 --> 00:32:04.890
>> No problem.

602
00:32:04.890 --> 00:32:06.530
>> Hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

603
00:32:06.530 --> 00:32:09.500
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

605

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike continue their look into SQL injection. This time they demonstrate how to perform blind SQL injection. They also use sqlmap to automate the process of detecting and exploiting SQL injection flaws.
episodes.title: SQL Injection Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:08.319
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:12.630

4

exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV.

Daniel Lowrie.

16

passwords out of a database that's
>> Being fronted by a web front end,

most organizations nowadays,

Product information, prices,

take over the machines.

Just the SQL injection
being able to get access

28

Is dangerous enough.

30

31

So you gotta make sure to sanitize

32

33

That's the whole purpose of us testing

34

And, remember, like we always like to say,

35
00:01:42.106 --> 00:01:44.050

>> Well, actually try it at home,

00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:48.720
just not against machines that you don't

37
00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:51.010
that you own personally.

38
00:01:51.010 --> 00:01:53.930
So that being said,
let's jump back into SQL.

39

Where do we leave off?

40

Well, in the previous episode,

We were getting errors that let us

00:02:09.760 --> 00:02:11.210
out of the database, which we did.

We got a couple of users and their

00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:18.660
You just run it through a decrypter and

00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:19.160
No big deal.

But what happens if the site

48
00:02:24.660 --> 00:02:30.390
You type in a string in the URL, or

and it just comes back,
or just nothing happens.

50
00:02:33.510 --> 00:02:36.260

I throw in the towel and I walk away.

51
00:02:36.260 --> 00:02:37.690
>> That's right,
security through obscurity.

52
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:40.480
It's so stinking hard,
this must be not worth my time.

53
00:02:40.480 --> 00:02:43.880
No, it doesn't mean you're done, just
means you got to try a different door,

54
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:45.480
right, we just gotta try a different door.

55
00:02:45.480 --> 00:02:47.910
And that's where blind SQL
injection comes into play.

56
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:51.680
So we're not gonna be seeing any errors,
which is why they call it blind, right?

57
00:02:51.680 --> 00:02:58.470
You're not seeing anything back,
at least not overtly.

58
00:02:58.470 --> 00:02:59.860
>> Yeah, not quite as obvious.

59
00:02:59.860 --> 00:03:01.200
>> Not as obvious.

60
00:03:01.200 --> 00:03:05.170
So you gotta be really
keenly looking at the site.

61
00:03:05.170 --> 00:03:08.960
For any difference in what you saw before,

62
00:03:08.960 --> 00:03:11.600
before you hit that enter key,
and pushed your SQL.

63
00:03:11.600 --> 00:03:14.060
>> You know I love those games where
they show you two pictures and

64
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:15.600
you try to figure out what
the difference is between the two?

65
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:16.680
>> Yeah.
>> I mean it's kind of what

66
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:17.310
you're doing here.

67
00:03:17.310 --> 00:03:18.330
>> Yeah, I like that analogy.

68
00:03:18.330 --> 00:03:19.100
That's really good.

69
00:03:19.100 --> 00:03:20.700
You're sitting there going.

70
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:21.935
The banana is green.

71
00:03:21.935 --> 00:03:23.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> I see what's going on,

72
00:03:23.870 --> 00:03:26.660
I'll circle that, I love the funny papers,
it's so much fun.

73
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:27.190
>> Yeah.

74
00:03:27.190 --> 00:03:30.190
>> So, yeah, kind of the idea,
you're looking for a difference.

75
00:03:30.190 --> 00:03:34.190
And any difference might be
that key to let you know well,

76
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:39.090
something has changed, cuz if this
sequel statement didn't go through

77
00:03:39.090 --> 00:03:41.200
It would've just not done anything.

78
00:03:41.200 --> 00:03:44.950
If it was sanitized it would just give me
normal, the same exact blue pipe print.

79
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:47.820
So, look out for changes, and

80
00:03:47.820 --> 00:03:51.812
then we'll take a look if that doesn't
happen on what you can continue to do.

81
00:03:51.812 --> 00:03:56.740
All right, so let's look at blind SQL
injection, let me get our website back up.

82
00:03:56.740 --> 00:03:59.240
Here it is, remember we have those
lovely passwords and everything.

83
00:03:59.240 --> 00:04:01.230
I didn't move away from it.

84
00:04:01.230 --> 00:04:04.560
I left it up for you guys to look at,
so you remember what we were doing.

85
00:04:04.560 --> 00:04:11.590
But let's go just to,
back to good old this, right?

86
00:04:11.590 --> 00:04:15.190
That standard page we started off with,
fantastic.

87
00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:17.880
What you can do with BLAST 2,

88
00:04:17.880 --> 00:04:21.930
let's pretend that this site
does not give us errors.

89
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:23.650
When we type in bad SQL, all right?

90
00:04:23.650 --> 00:04:27.480
So, remember we did the single quote and
hit Return and it gets us here.

91
00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:29.320
Let's pretend that doesn't happen.

92
00:04:29.320 --> 00:04:30.560
Okay, so.

93
00:04:30.560 --> 00:04:32.410
>> I don't see anything,
I don't know where I should look.

94
00:04:32.410 --> 00:04:35.106
>> Which is fine, [LAUGH] pay no attention
to the man behind the curtain, right?

95
00:04:35.106 --> 00:04:38.103
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, what you would do for

96
00:04:38.103 --> 00:04:43.570
blind SQL injection testing is
throw at it some actual SQL.

97
00:04:43.570 --> 00:04:45.500
And see if it does something.

98
00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:49.780
So that's basically you're looking for
a true false kinda thing at this point.

99
00:04:49.780 --> 00:04:53.580
If something occurs then you know
that your SQL command got executed.

100
00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:55.900
If nothing occurs,
you get back to a site or

101
00:04:55.900 --> 00:05:02.150
just their site takes you to a regular
page, then you know that it's not working.

102
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:02.790
So let's do that.

103
00:05:02.790 --> 00:05:08.407
Let's try our and statement we'll say and

104
00:05:08.407 --> 00:05:14.500
one equals one semi colon
harsh on that's it.

105
00:05:14.500 --> 00:05:19.250
And I'm getting an error obviously
because that but you wanna try that and

106
00:05:19.250 --> 00:05:22.390
I wanna try something so
that's a correct statement.

107
00:05:22.390 --> 00:05:24.270
One does equals one.

108
00:05:24.270 --> 00:05:27.440
And we're tagging that on to the end of
this little SQL statement right here.

109
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:30.730
So one does equal one, that's good.

110
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:32.170
It's a correct statement, it's true.

111
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:36.110
If you don't see anything change,
then that's fine.

112
00:05:37.190 --> 00:05:37.821
If that doesn't work,

113
00:05:37.821 --> 00:05:41.450
you're not getting some output
try something that's not right.

114
00:05:41.450 --> 00:05:45.130
We try to force a problem, per say, right.

115
00:05:45.130 --> 00:05:46.120
So try one equals two.

116
00:05:48.080 --> 00:05:48.740
Right?

117
00:05:48.740 --> 00:05:49.870
Maybe the website changes.

118
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:53.280
You're looking for
those subtle hints, right?

119
00:05:53.280 --> 00:05:56.580
And that's basically
where you would do that.

120
00:05:56.580 --> 00:06:00.310
If those don't work what you can do is

121
00:06:00.310 --> 00:06:04.690
try a very common technique is to build
in yourself like a little test mechanism.

122
00:06:04.690 --> 00:06:07.560
Mechanism to see if they're
actually working or not.

123
00:06:07.560 --> 00:06:10.690
If you're putting these things in and
you're not seeing any changes

124
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:15.630
it doesn't necessarily mean your SQL
isn't actually getting executed.

125
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:17.410
It just means you're not seeing it.

126
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:22.520
So you wanna do something that
will make it more obvious

127
00:06:22.520 --> 00:06:26.150
that your SQL is being Executed.

128
00:06:26.150 --> 00:06:29.890
And one of the most common ways to do
that is to call in the sleep function.

129
00:06:29.890 --> 00:06:33.160
Which basically you say
sleep x amount of seconds.

130
00:06:33.160 --> 00:06:37.322
And so if I say five seconds, the website
will hang for five seconds because

131
00:06:37.322 --> 00:06:41.170
it's waiting five seconds before
it issues the rest of the command.

132
00:06:42.170 --> 00:06:42.840
Okay?

133
00:06:42.840 --> 00:06:47.790
So if the website hangs, I know that
it's taking SQL injection, right?

134
00:06:47.790 --> 00:06:50.510
Because I've injected
the sleep function into there.

135
00:06:50.510 --> 00:06:53.970
If it doesn't hang, then I know
that it's not vulnerable, right?

136
00:06:53.970 --> 00:06:59.340
And then if it does hang, I could
continue to use sleep to verify that my

137
00:06:59.340 --> 00:07:05.340
code is working, cuz sleep is getting
issued, it is being executed.

138
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:07.430
And then the rest of it should
be executed as well, right?

139
00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:10.340
If it doesn't, if it doesn't hang,
then I know my SQL was bad.

140
00:07:10.340 --> 00:07:11.840
I need to go back and take a look.

141
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:16.150
Maybe I malformed it,
I gotta make sure to verify my syntax.

142
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:17.110
All that good stuff.

143
00:07:17.110 --> 00:07:20.350
So we can kinda use it as
a true-false statement for us.

144
00:07:20.350 --> 00:07:24.640
If my website hangs,
that SQL statement went through.

145
00:07:24.640 --> 00:07:28.170
If it doesn't hang, then I did something
wrong and I need to try again.

146
00:07:28.170 --> 00:07:29.740
All right, so let's try that.

147
00:07:29.740 --> 00:07:31.090
How does that look in the URL?

148
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:35.890
Obviously, that's where we like to
hang out and back this monkey up so

149
00:07:35.890 --> 00:07:38.550
I can make sure I get my thing correctly.

150
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:40.000
Is it -sleep?

151
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:42.410
Yeah, there we go.

152
00:07:42.410 --> 00:07:47.008
So we just add -sleep and
then how many seconds you want to sleep.

153
00:07:47.008 --> 00:07:53.569
So we say -sleep, and then I say open
parentheses, five, close parentheses.

154
00:07:53.569 --> 00:07:54.555
I hit return.

155
00:07:54.555 --> 00:07:56.674

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike begin their discussion on password attacks. They explain how dictionary attacks are performed and how dictionaries are created or obtained. They also look at brute force attacks and tools used to perform them.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike continue their look into password attacks. They look at where passwords are stored in both Linux and Windows, and how to obtain them. They also demonstrate how to perform a passing the hash attack.

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike discuss different types of port redirection. They look at port forwarding and SSH tunneling. They also demonstrate remote port forwarding with SSH.
episodes.title: Port Redirection
